resources.string: Biodiversity4all is a member of the iNaturalist Network in Portugal. Would you like to use this network to localize your experience and share data accordingly?
The main iNaturalist Network. Clicking OK will set your app as part of the global iNaturalist network.

iNaturalist is a member of the iNaturalist Network in Mexico. Would you like to use this network to localize your experience and share data accordingly?

NatureWatch NZ is a member of the iNaturalist Network in New Zealand. Would you like to use this network to localize your experience and share data accordingly?

Google requires us to ask for permission to access your contacts in order to use your Google Account, even though we do not access your contacts for any reason. If you deny this permission, you will need to sign up or login with a username and password.

A Facebook-fiókod zárolva van. A folytatáshoz, kérjük, jelentkezz be a www.facebook.com oldalon.
A fiók hozzákapcsolásához nyisd meg a mobilkészülékeden a Facebook alkalmazást, és nézd meg az értesítéseket.
Te irányítasz – válaszd ki, milyen adatokat szeretnél megosztani az alkalmazásokkal.

"This will download %1$s of data so you can use this guide even when you don't have Internet access."

Geoprivacy is a setting you can make on your observations that controls how the spatial coordinates (latitude and longitude) are displayed. Here are the options:
open - Everyone can see the coordinates unless the taxon is threatened.
obscured - Public coordinates shown as a random point within a 0.2 by 0.2 degree area that contains the true coordinates, which works out to about a 22x22 km square area of uncertainty at the equator, decreasing as you approach the poles. True coordinates are only visible to you and the curators of projects to which you add the observation.
private - Coordinates completely hidden from public maps, true coordinates only visible to you and the curators of projects to which you add the observation.

Note that curators of individual projects can always see the coordinates regardless of your geoprivacy setting, so if you are concerned about who has access to the coordinates you should be sure you trust the curators of the projects in which you participate.

"I don't know but I'm sure this is %1$s."
iNaturalist is a joint initiative by the California Academy of Sciences and the National Geographic Society.

iNaturalist is made by every single person who participates in our community. The people who build the software, maintain our infrastructure, and foster collaborations are Amanda Bullington, Yaron Budowski, Tony Iwane, Patrick Leary, Scott Loarie, Abhas Misraraj, Alex Shepard, Carrie Seltzer, and Ken-ichi Ueda (our former designer Joelle Belmonte designed much of the current Android app). Caltech and Cornell University helped develop the computer vision system that recognizes species from photographs. We thank Grant Van Horn, Serge Belongie, and Pietro Perona for this work. More information may be found at visipedia.org
The iNaturalist Network is a framework for localizing the iNaturalist community on national scales. Such national focus can help make nature more accessible to people of different backgrounds.

"These are links to ancestors of this particular taxon. They are in order from coarser to more refined. Use these links to move up and down the Tree of Life. For example, if you don't know what an organism is, but know what grouping it falls into, tap on a taxon from the list to view more information about it."
